thread.title: Live News: Ireland misses out on EU jobs | Business Post
thread.title_full: Live News: Ireland misses out on EU jobs | Business Post

title: Live News: Ireland misses out on EU jobs | Business Post
text:
Live News Catch up on Tuesday’s news: Irish hauliers call for Govt support over Holyhead closure; RIP.ie to introduce €100 death notice fee Bite-sized servings of the latest in business, tech and current affairs
Eoin O'Hare 17:02 Welcome to the Business Post ’s Live News section. We’re here all day to keep you up to date on developments in business, tech and current affairs.
17.00 - Irish hauliers call for financial support over Holyhead closure The Irish Road Haulage Association (IRHA) has called for immediate financial support from the government as the extended closure of Holyhead Port threatens Ireland’s supply chains.
Holyhead Port will remain closed until at least January 15 , with all ferry services cancelled until then, officials have confirmed earlier today.
The announcement means the key port for Irish-GB trade will have remained closed for over month, after sustaining serious damage during Storm Darragh earlier this month.
In a statement, the IRHA warned that the disruption has already caused huge financial losses for hauliers, with many struggling to reroute goods through alternative UK ports.
Ger Hyland, President of the IRHA, said the situation requires urgent government intervention:“ We are calling for financial support as a matter of urgency – not February or March, but now.”
16.45 - RIP.ie to introduce €100 death notice fee Death notice website RIP.ie is introducing a fee for submitting death notices, The Journal reports .
A €100 fee will be charged to funeral directors for each death notice from January.
A spokesperson said the fees would support “the development and enhancement” of the service.
16.30 - Iseq closes in the red The Iseq All Share has closed marginally in the red, down 0.17 per cent at 9.689.79.
Origin Enterprises was the biggest riser, up 1.38 per cent, while Kerry Group (up 1.32 per cent) and Glanbia (up 1.19 per cent) also saw gains.
Kenmare Resources was the biggest faller, down 5.34 per cent, with Irish Continental Group (down 3.37 per cent) and PTSB (down 2 per cent) also hit with losses.
16.15 - Fund managers ‘super bullish’ on US stocks ahead of year-end Fund managers are extremely optimistic about US equities ahead of the end of the year with record-high allocations to US stocks and record-low allocations to cash, according to the latest Bank of America global fund manager survey.
The survey, which was conducted from December 6 to December 12, showed “super bullish” sentiment, the report said on Tuesday.
Kathleen Gallagher reports.
16.00 - Trump’s tariff and tax plans a risk to Irish economy, warns Central Bank The Central Bank has cautioned that proposed tariffs and tax reforms from the Trump administration pose a significant risk to the Irish economy, particularly for US multinationals operating in Ireland.
In its latest Quarterly Bulletin, the bank highlighted the potential for job losses, reduced investment, and lower corporation tax revenues if these changes are implemented.
RTÉ has the story.
15.45 - Dublin Bus agrees ‘massive’ €2 billion contract with NTA Dublin Bus has agreed a new contract with the National Transport Authority (NTA) worth €2 billion over the next five years, which will see it operate the bus routes across the greater Dublin area.
The contract is the primary source of income for the bus company, which last year recorded revenues of €334.8 million, €325 million of which came from its public service obligation payment agreed with the NTA.
Ellie Donnelly has the exclusive.
15.30 - Holyhead to be closed until January 15 ‘at earliest’, says Port operator Holyhead Port will remain closed until at least January 15, with all ferry services cancelled until then, officials have confirmed.
The announcement means the key port for Irish-GB trade will have remained closed for over month, after sustaining serious damage during Storm Darragh earlier this month.
It has already caused major trade and travel disruption ahead of festive period, with key freight and supply chain links hit hard by the closure.
Dominic McGrath reports.
15.15 - Meta hit by new €251m fine from Data Protection Commission Meta has been fined €251 million by the Data Protection Commission over a personal data breach that impacted 29 million Facebook users, of which 3 million were based in the EU.
The latest penalty brings to more than €2.75 billion the amount Meta has been fined by the Data Protection Commission in recent years.
Charlie Taylor has the story.
15.00 - Dublin private equity firm Melior acquires NI holiday park company Melior, the Dublin-based private equity company, has acquired a majority stake in Blair’s, an Antrim-based holiday park firm.
The private equity firm plans to expand Blair’s with the acquisition of more sites around the North, adding to its four sites in Antrim.
Founded in 1978 by the late Tom Blair, the holiday park firm is now headed up by Blair’s nephew Colin Mayrs.
Read the full story in the Irish News .
14.45 - NYSE falls upon opening The NYSE, meanwhile, similarly opened in the red, registering a 0.48 per cent fall.
14.30 - Nasdaq opens in the red On Wall Street, the Nasdaq has opened with a drop of 0.42 per cent, after it began the week with a solid showing on Monday.
Photo by lucky-photographer 14.15 - Car purchase and online shopping drive US retail growth A surge in car purchases and strong online shopping drove a jump in US retail sales in November, obscuring a more mixed overall spending picture.
The value of retail purchases, not adjusted for inflation, climbed 0.7 per cent in the month, while sales excluding cars inched up 0.2 per cent.
Bloomberg has the full figure breakdown .
14.00 - UK wages rise faster than expected Wages in the UK are rising far faster than expected after a year of slowing.
Data from the national statistics office shows that average pay rose by 5.2 per cent in the three months to October, much higher than the rate expected by economists polled by Reuters.
Read more on Sky News .
Photo by Rosemary Calvert 13.45 - Sotheby’s to close Dublin office Auction firm Sotheby’s will close its Dublin office in the coming months as part of a series of global cutbacks.
A spokesperson for the company told the Irish Independent that it would continue to serve its Irish clients despite the closure, with further details to be announced.
Sotheby’s dedicated Irish art sale at the peak of the Celtic Tiger saw the likes of Galen Weston and Michael Smurfit compete for and spend seven-figure sums on paintings by Irish artists.
Read the full story in the Irish Independent .
13.30 - DPC fines Meta €251 million The DPC has fined Meta €251 million for a personal data breach impacting 29 million Facebook accounts globally.
The breach, reported by Meta in September 2018 and remedied shortly after its discovery, affected around 3 million users in Europe.
Read more on RTÉ .
13.15 - Holyhead closure not to blame for £500 flights, Michael O’Leary says The £500 price tag on some one-way London to Dublin flights this Christmas has nothing to do with the closure of Holyhead Port, according to Michael O’Leary.
The Ryanair chief told RTÉ that the Dublin Airport passenger cap is to blame for the high prices, as it has resulted in “a gross shortage of seats” in and out of the capital over the festive period.
Megan O’Brien has the full story .
Photo by Fergal Phillips 13.00 - Navantia nears £70m Harland & Wolff takeover Harland & Wolff, the beleaguered Titanic builder, is on the brink of a £70 million government-backed rescue deal.
According to Sky News, ministers hope to announce on Thursday that H&W and its four shipyards are being acquired by Spanish shipbuilder Navantia after months of negotiations.
Read the full story here .
12.45 - Coimisiún na Meán to work with EU Commission in TikTok election probe The European Commission has opened a probe into TikTok’s suspected failure to assess and limit risks to election integrity following last month’s Romanian presidential election.
Coimisiún na Meán, the Irish media watchdog, will work closely with the Commission in its investigation.
Read the full story in The Irish Times .
12.30 - Ronan O’Gara snapped up by Consello Ronan O’Gara has joined Consello, the global corporate and financial advisory firm, as a senior advisor on the firm’s leadership development, talent and business transformation team.
The ex-Munster player and current La Rochelle coach joins the likes of Gary Neville and Paul McGinley on the firm’s leadership development, talent and business transformation team, led by former Tipperary hurling boss Liam Sheedy.
Consello works with C-Suites, board directors, and senior leaders in Ireland and internationally to design and implement strategies that attract, build, and sustain high performing teams.
Read more on the announcement from Emma Hanrahan .
12.15 - Pfizer revenue guidance in line with analysts Pfizer’s forecast for its 2025 revenue is in line with analyst projections, as the company attempts to fend off claims by an activist investor that it is being mismanaged.
Next year will see turnover total $61 billion to $64 billion (€58 billion to €61 billion), the pharma giant said today, while Wall Street analysts surveyed by Bloomberg expected an average of $63.2 billion.
Read the full story here .
12.00 - Micheál Martin to back Verona Murphy in Ceann Comhairle bid Micheál Martin will support the nomination of Verona Murphy, the independent TD, for the role of Ceann Comhairle when the Dáil sits on Wednesday, Seán Ó Fearghaíl has said.
The outgoing Ceann Comhairle and Fianna Fáil TD told RTÉ on Tuesday that his party leader had spoken to him last night and confirmed he would support the nomination of Murphy, the Wexford TD who is a member of the nine-strong Regional Group of independents.
It comes despite both Ó Fearghaíl, who has served two terms in the chair, and fellow party TD John McGuinness putting their names forward for the role.
The Business Post has more .
11.45 - Wall Street bets Trump will fuel further dollar gains Investors on Wall Street are betting the US dollar will make further gains after its recent rally, even hitting parity with the euro, in a challenge to president-elect Donald Trump’s stated desire for a weaker currency, reports the Financial Times.
The dollar has soared 6.2 per cent since the start of October, marking its best quarter since the early stages of 2022 when the Federal Reserve’s interest rate raising campaign began.
The Financial Times has more .
11.30 - Will Goodbody leaves RTÉ to head up AIB external comms Will Goodbody, RTÉ’s business editor, is departing the national broadcaster to take over as AIB’s head of external communications.
He is taking over from Kathleen Barrington, the one-time journalist who has spent the last four years in the role. Barrington is understood to be retiring.
Having spent the last 20 years with RTÉ, Goodbody will take on the job February 2025, the bank confirmed.
Our banking correspondent Donal MacNamee has the exclusive .
11.15 - German business expectations plummet German business expectations have plummeted this month, with economic difficulties increasing the chances of a change in government ahead of a snap election.
Clemens Fuest, the president of the Ifo Institute, told Bloomberg that the German government needed to prioritise economic growth to tackle the “chronic” weakness in the country’s economy.
Read more here .
11.00 - Tullow Oil takeover talks halt Talk of a potential takeover of Tullow Oil by American peer Kosmos Energy has halted, as the latter confirmed it will not make an offer.
In a stock exchange notice on Tuesday Kosmos said that while it had been in “very preliminary discussions” over an offer for the Africa-focused oil and gas exploration and production company, it “does not intent to make a firm offer”.
Our markets correspondent Kathleen Gallagher has more .
10.45 - Qantas to pay out $120m to sacked baggage handlers Qantas is set to pay out $120 million to almost 2000 baggage handlers the Australian airline illegally sacked in 2020.
The airline reached an agreement with the workers’ union after years of wrangling that saw Qantas make unsuccessful appeals to the Australian federal court and high court.
Read the full story in the Guardian .
10.30 - Emirates sees record demand on Dublin-Dubai route Some 450,000 passengers will have travelled between Ireland to Dubai and beyond on Emirates in 2024, with “record demand” on the route, according to a statement from the carrier.
Dubai retained its position as Emirates’ top destination from Ireland, while this year also saw significant growth in demand for Australia, Thailand, South Africa, Vietnam, and Indian Ocean destinations such as the Maldives, Mauritius, and Seychelles, the Dubai-based airline said.
Ellie Donnelly has more .
Anita Thomas, country manager for Emirates airline in Ireland. Picture: Fergal Phillips 10.15 - Bord Gáis Energy reaches 60% female executive representation Bord Gáis Energy's executive management team is made up of more women than men for the first time ever.
Female representation rose this year to 60 per cent from 40 per cent in 2023, while the wider senior management team reached 44 per cent in the same period.
Kerry McConnell, the Bord Gáis Energy CFO since November last year , said that the firm was not complacent about gender balance or diversity despite the progress made.
RTÉ has the full story .
10.00 - Carlsberg’s €4bn takeover of Britvic approved by UK watchdog Carlsberg’s £3.3 billion (€4 billion) takeover of Britvic, the UK soft drinks maker, has been given the go-ahead by the country’s competition watchdog.
The Competition and Markets Authority cleared the proposed deal a day before the deadline for the first phase of its probe into the transaction.
Read the full story in The Guardian .
09.45 - Government in Mercosur trade deal U-turn The government has eased its opposition to the Mercosur trade deal, despite Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael campaigning strongly against it during the general election.
Speaking on RTÉ’s Morning Ireland, Peter Burke, the Fine Gael enterprise minister, said that his party had opposed the trade deal between the EU and the south American Mercosur trade bloc during the election because of the potential impact on farmers.
Read the full story here .
Photo by Barry Cronin 09.30 - Legal and staff costs drive near €1bn loss for TikTok’s Irish arm despite surging revenues The Irish arm of TikTok recorded a loss after tax of more than $1 billion (€953 million) last year despite surging revenues, amid rising legal and staff costs.
According to latest filings made by TikTok Technology Limited, last year’s loss compares to a $7.6 million profit made in 2022.
Charlie Taylor and Vish Gain took a look through the numbers .
09.15 - EU carmakers raise petrol car prices and ready EV discounts ahead of new emissions rules European car manufacturers are raising prices of petrol cars and readying discounts on EVs, as they steel themselves for tougher emissions rules that could eat into the industry’s shrinking profits.
The EU’s cap on carbon emissions from cars is set to be slashed from the new year, meaning at least a fifth of all car sales by most companies must be EVs.
Just 13 per cent of all sales in the bloc so far this year were electric, however.
Read more from Reuters .
09.00 - Fine Grain finalises deal for Johnny Ronan’s Connaught House Fine Grain Property, the commercial real estate investor founded and led by Colin MacDonald, has confirmed it has finalised a deal for Connaught House, part of the property portfolio of developer Johnny Ronan.
The Business Post reported earlier this month that the deal was near completion and that agents acting on behalf of Nicholas O’Dwyer and Michael McAteer of Grant Thornton were guiding €80 million for Connaught House, but that the property was believed to have sold for just over €60 million.
Vish Gain has the rest .
08.45 - TikTok lodges Supreme Court appeal to ban TikTok has asked the US Supreme Court to temporarily block a law to force its Chinese parent ByteDance to divest from the social platform by January 19 or face a ban.
TikTok and ByteDance filed an emergency request to the court for an injunction to halt the incoming ban on the social media app, which is used by around 170 million Americans, while the companies appeal a lower court's ruling that upheld the law.
Read more on RTÉ .
Photo by Andrew Harrer 08.30 - Coimisiún na Meán to oppose X legal challenge Ireland’s media watchdog is set to oppose a legal challenge taken by X, the Elon Musk-owned social media platform formerly known as Twitter, against new online safety rules.
Coimisiún na Meán said that it would engage in the litigation process after Twitter International Unlimited Company lodged a judicial review against the new online safety code.
The code requires video-sharing platforms to implement measures protecting children from harmful content, including age verification and parental controls.
Read the full story in The Irish Independent .
08.15 - FTSE opens in red Across the Irish Sea, the FTSE has also opened in the red with a 0.54 per cent drop.
Frankfurt saw a similar fall as the Dax slipped 0.45 per cent upon opening.
Back in Dublin, the Iseq is down 0.25 per cent in early trading, with Maldron Hotels operator Dalata leading losses with a 0.80 per cent fall.
08.00 - Iseq All Share opens in red The Iseq All Share has opened in the red this morning, slipping a further 0.11 per cent from Monday’s drop.
Photo by David Soanes Photography 07.45 - Thousands of AIB customers to be refunded after cancelled credit cards charged stamp duty Thousands of AIB customers are to be refunded after the lender charged stamp duty on already-cancelled credit cards.
The bank wrote to close to 10,000 affected customers in the last week, with each set to receive an average payout of about €90.
Customers do not have to take action to get the automatic refund.
See The Irish Times for more .
07.30 - Housing body deals risk public finances, senior official warns A senior finance official raised concerns with the Department of Housing earlier this around the risk to taxpayers posed by approved housing bodies (AHBs) and the Land Development Agency (LDA) funding construction deals.
Writing to his housing counterpart in April, Department of Fianance secretary general John Hogan said that there has been a “fundamental shift in risk appetite” by AHBs and by the state in forward-funding the development of apartments and houses “at an increased scale”.
Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael each pledged before the recent general election to use AHBs and the LDA to ramp up housebuilding.
Read the full story in The Irish Times .
07.15 - Chinese markets react to fresh growth and budget figures Overnight in Asia, the main indexes have bounced back from early losses following reports that China is set to announce a 5 per cent growth target for 2025 along with a 4 per cent budget deficit, analysts at Deutsche Bank noted.
“There has been talk of such an expanded deficit number in the last couple of weeks but if that is the growth target the market will likely conclude that the authorities will have to be serious about stimulus,” wrote Jim Reid of Deutsche in a note circulated this morning.
Hong Kong’s Hang Seng is down 0.22 per cent, its bounce back receding somewhat from earlier this morning, while Shanghai’s CSI rallied to grow 0.26 per cent.
In Japan, the Nikkei fell 0.24 per cent, while South Korea’s Kospi saw a fall of 1.29 per cent.
07.00 - Good morning Good morning from the Business Post .
Eoin O’Hare here with you today to keep you up-to-date on all the latest news as it happens.
We are leading the Business Post site this morning with Sarah Collins report from Brussels on the the disappointment behind the scenes with Ireland’s failure to secure cabinet positions with European commissioners. Is this another example of Ireland’s star on the wane in the EU?
